author: dani136
title: Care Opinion website
body: May I tell new people this site is tremendous, it reaches the people who you wouldn't normally manage to contact, I've used this before and the responses from my local hospital was successful, it's good to have a such supportive site.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: dvh
title: Super care for my mum
body:
My mum was booked in with a leg infection and a nasty looking growth on her chest. She is elderly and quite frail. She is now looking so much better and is ready for discharge. I want to say how well she has been looked after, great information and support from the nursing team every time I called up to check on her and support during a final discharge meeting held on the ward.  
Big thanks to the team on ward 7 south.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: mikedubya
title: Engaging during lockdown.
body: I finally downloaded teams and logged into a group session although because of technical problems I was too late but did manage to speak with Simon my keyworker. Its a good feeling to now be able to communicate and engage as boredom and isolation have become a small issue, I'm lucky to be living with my family and have access to a lovely garden and the seafront though. I am looking forward to taking part in any and all online activities going forward now so a positive move made today.

title: Excellent service
body: I just wanted to feedback about the excellent service I received today in the MRI department. It isn’t nice to have an MRI scan, it’s noisy and claustrophobic, the staff were extremely kind and reassuring, especially given the very challenging situation they face with covid. Due to my nerves I didn’t remember any of their names but Thankyou for making today easier for me.

readBy.name: Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Efficient Department
body:
Most greatful to Ophthalmology for contiuning to hold the macular clinic during a time of great strain for the hospital.

   The department is the most efficient I have ever visited, without any sense of being rushed. I seldom spend more than an hour there for an appointment involving an acuity test, OCT scan, injection and may also include seeing a consultant or clinician.

  Again my thanks to you all.

title: Great service
body:
On my first dealing with the surgery I phoned for an appointment at 08.20 in the morning, after a 5 min wait I spoke to a pleasant and polite receptionist who took my details etc and told me a Doctor would phone me back.
At 09.10 the Doctor phoned, we discussed my problem and he offered me an appointment at 09.50.
I visited the surgery and was seen promptly and the Doctor needed to refer me for a hospital visit.
Before 11.00 the following morning the hospital phoned me and made an appointment for me on 09/06/20.
This was fantastic service from the NHS In these torrid times and I give them my full respect.

title: Very efficient
body: I have had excellent and speedy care from everyone. The quick response to my problem and the efficiency with dealing with them has been second to none.

title: Good Practice
body: Although the procedure was not possible, I was not disappointed, the staff made me feel totally at ease and explained everything.

title: Web Site
body: Useless! I tried to check times for a blood test which isn't listed as a department. The numpty administrator who set up the 'phone system has it totally wrong. I spoke very clearly stating that I wished to speak to the blood test clinic. The automatic reply asked me, in a very muffled manner, if I wanted Chorley or Preston. 3 times I said Chorley and it couldn't understand!! Eventually I was answered by the switchboard who immediately gave me the information I require. Support for front line staff, yes! Administrators No!! By the way, this is the web site for Chorley & South Ribble Hospital. The spell check is highlighting the words Chorley and Ribble as misspellings!!!!!!!!!

readBy.name: Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Worst practice
body: I am 78 Male have not needed any medical help for many years since March you resolved a  constipation problem but since then I have been dramatically loosing weight (I cannot get my data on Doctor link) as of todays date my BMI is 13.6 I need to do something about my weight - Other people in the area believe that because of my age you should have at least visited me, as I have not seen a Doctor for many years  since I have been registered with the  practice - I have had phone contact with young Doctors and you have done home tests - I need to know where this weight problem is going  Please advise - Urgent.

title: Very unhelpful
body:
It took me 9 self referrals to get an assessment with Canada house and my 1st assessment I got brushed off as I was medicated.

About 4 month's later and many referrals again I got a new assesment which was good and was passed to secondary care

Secondary care identified some things that the initial assessment hadn't but said they couldn't change anything so have been battling this. 

Have actually got a gp who is working to get me the support I need and sent across another referral this was held today 25 mins late the Dr continually spoke over me and diddnt give me the opportunity to expand on things and then told me he had no more time.

When will I actually get someone who understands what I need and the time to talk

readBy.name: Kent and Medway NHS and Social Care Partnership Trust

author: Chantel
title: Telephone consultation
body:
Due to the current situation I had a consultation via the telephone. It was fine.  
I think if it had been a Consultant I had not seen before I would have preferred a video link. No parking problems - a real plus.

readBy.name: Oxford University Hospitals NHS foundation Trust Haematology Department

title: Very Good Practice
body: I attended the endoscopy unit on the 27/5/2020. From the time I arrived on the unit until the time I left, everyone I came into contact with was very professional and caring. Cannot praise them enough!

author: Manicfifer
title: Covid screening
body:
I had been asked to arrive 10-15 mins early for ophthalmology as I would have Covid-19 screening before appointment. Arrived in plenty time, entered hospital walking through main entrance. On walking through corridor to department noticed floor signs telling me if I hadn't been screen I should turn back. Where to though. Asked a couple staff members who were approaching and they directed me back to main entrance area. Had walked right past the testing area. Hadn't noticed the small low level signs. Once taken for test no problems. Person friendly and polite.  
Would suggest signs are placed at eye level with directional arrow so that numpties such as myself actually notice the area.  
At least the floor signs further on made me stop and go back albeit with help with directions

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Exemplary service
body: I attended the minor injury unit, during Covid-19 lockdown, as my ring finger had swollen and I sadly needed my wedding cutting off ........ from the moment I arrived, the staff were helpful, supportive, very courteous, efficient and I was out less than 30 minutes .......  thank you

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor Service
body: Getting through to the surgery and getting an appointment is an absolute lottery. A few doctors are good and take time to hear you out and do something, rest are either flapping pages on their books once you tell them the symptoms or just prescribe an medicine without much thought to get you out of there. Had an appointment last week for blood checks and had to wait 20 mins although there was nobody in the surgery except me and another lady. Got a text the following day saying doctor needs to discuss your results therefore book an appointment. Called and was  on hold for nearly 45 mins before they answered, and booked a telephone appointment for 8:35 in the morning. As I write this review its 9:30 and still waiting for a call!  Could understand if it was middle of the day and they could be running late, but having been to the surgery and seeing for myself how there is hardly anybody attending in person and choosing the first slot of the day, this is really poor service.

title: GREAT PRACTICE AND STAFF
body: Had a minor surgery done I was extremely nervous Doctor talked me through step by step reassured me at all times.  This made me feel at ease and I would not hesitate to have any more surgery done again.  All staff are professional, friendly, and approachable keep up the good work Aegis.

title: Amazing service
body: I have been in touch with my GP a couple of times during Covid-19. I am not a frequent visitor to the doctor's. I have nothing but praise for the way the Derby Medical Centre is currently working. Questions and enquiries to the online service are promptly answered and I could not believe that I received by blood test results online in a matter of days. I am really grateful for the help and support my GP has given me.

title: Fabulous Practice
body: Wonderful reception team, helpful.  Been patients for over 50 years!  Would not dream of changing.  Great doctors, always listen and treat us with respect. thank you.

title: Excellent service and very efficient
body: I brought my newborn to the hospital with serious illness requiring urgent care and the Accident and Emergency provided what would be a life saving treatment and excellent follow up care provided by Paediatric Intensive care  unit. There are no words to describe amazing response from the hospital staff till my newborn was fully back to normal and well. I am so thankful for their efforts and they will hold special place in our family’s heart forever. I wish all the best to the amazing Royal London Hospital staff and the NHS for their amazing service to its community.

title: Disappointed
body:
I'd always been really happy with this practice and the doctors and nurses have always been excellent and caring. I had excellent care over the telephone recently. But then things seemed to fall apart. Firstly, there was no communication over an appointment I was due to have in March, which I'd booked 21 days in advance. I learnt through someone else on twitter that all appointments had been switched to telephone. I had no information from the practice and there was no information online. Furthermore, the ability to book appointments online was removed without any communication to patients, or information on the website. I couldn't change an appointment I already had booked without calling, at a practice where phone lines are unreliable and frequently going down. There may have been a good reason why this was removed, but removing it without informing patients seems remiss. Newsletters with no helpful information are occasionally sent out, but when it comes to things patients actually want to know - like getting rid of 72 hour appointments, introducing 21 day appointments, doctors leaving, online bookings being disabled - we hear nothing. 
Then, I was informed by text in early May that I should be shielding due to the covid pandemic. Since then I have heard nothing. I still haven't received a letter that would be helpful when making arrangements with my employer. I assume I was identified as vulnerable by my GP as I was not picked up earlier in the first 'wave' of shielding. So a phone call would have been appreciated - didn't need to be immediately, but eventually. This is life-changing advice. Out of the blue, with no time to prepare, I was told I should not leave my home until the end of June, living with complex health problems, and that's all I heard. Disappointed.

title: insensitive and difficult
body:
it took me and my partner several attempts to be seen at the early pregnancy unit despite repeat A&E visits and calls. We kept trying and calling until someone picked up the phone and told us we had clear symptoms that needed to be seen to.

When my partner went for a scan, to be told that we had lost the baby, the patient care was very poor. There was no empathy or care procedure and she was sent to a grieving room alone (due to the COViD outbreak) and was sat close to a staff member who was loudly swearing and complaining that there were too many patients for a sunny weekend and that they wanted to go home. it was completely unacceptable and insensitive.

title: Prompt and efficient service
body: Asked for a call back regarding severe leg pain. GP rang back promptly and assessed the situation thoroughly and clearly. Recommended same day appointment with another clinician (had name but lost piece of paper with it on) who thoroughly examined me safely (Full PPE) under current restrictions and made necessary appointment for blood tests and reported outcome to GP and advised a physio may be available when I do the bloods. GP texted me later in the day to set up back X-Ray. Overall I felt very well looked after and reassured by all clinicians and reception staff. Action was clear, prompt and appropriate. Reception staff were well informed, helpful and friendly.

title: Disappointed
body:
The doctors at this surgery have been extremely good but unfortunately that's where the good stops.
My husband and I received a message to tell us we would only be dealt with via econsult.
Meaning no further telephone consultations.
When I rang the surgery to explain my husband would be unable to do this, I was told I could do it for him.
I tried it once and vowed never again,in fact I gave up.
If I was unwell I wouldn't be able to cope with a generic system that goes on forever.
So my husband and I will be leaving this practice and joining another.
All we wanted was to talk to a doctor.

title: Great practice
body:
I would like to commend a doctor was working out of her field in A&E and provided me with outstanding care during the evening of Thursday 28th May. She was very professional, empathetic, thorough and explained everything carefully. She also listened extremely well. I could not have had better care anywhere. 
Thank you.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Change to phlebotomy clinic
body: My husband who is isolating from covid19 requires  a monthly blood test to monitor chronic kidney  disease. He made an wasted trip to the clinic for a blood test today because  there is no information  on the website informing patients that this is now appointment  only. Please can you amend  this so people at risk are not going out more than they have to.

author: Airdrie patient
title: Covid-19 visiting
body:
I sit here in my car writing this post as I can’t be in with my child because it’s my husbands turn ! I write this post not as a complaint as I understand the reason for restricting visiting during COVID but to give a little insight into how it feels to be separated from your critically ill child. A child has two parents who want to spend every moment with them especially since they don’t know if their child will see tomorrow! So only allowing one parent in at a time breaks the family unit and the support system. The support both parents provide for each other is vital in trying to stay afloat in this horrific situation! I have to sit in the car as there is no where else I am allowed to go. I sit here anxious and nervous as I feel so far away from my child and husband.  
I sit here alone trying to process what the next hour has in store for us! I plan how long it would take me to get to the PICU from the car park in an emergency! If an emergency happened would I make it in time? As I sit here alone I have no one to reassure me that’s it’s going to be ok. COVID is not going away any time soon! Children becoming sick still happens during COVID so I feel that the Scottish government and the health board need to realise and have a better understanding of the trauma being separated from your sick child causes and review the rules! Come and spend some time with me in the unit and perhaps gain a bit of insight! Thank you

title: Sincere Appreciation
body: Having called 111 in pain at circa 4.30am on Thursday 28th March the very professional, concerned and caring way I was dealt with  deserves recognition. Thank you for calling the ambulance which arrived within 10 minutes and after a number of tests my successful surgery meant I could go home on Friday. All the professionals I encountered during my worrying painful day were of note. Sincerre appreciation for the NHS in all its guises. Well done all.

title: Top quality telephone follow up
body: Some three weeks ago I requested an increase in my anti depressant medication because of a poor sleep pattern and related problems. Today I had the programmed follow up call from the practice with an extremely helpful member of staff who carried out the full questionnaire and then discussed my medication with me in detail. We agreed to continue at the present dose for another few weeks and then to have another review with a view to reducing the dose. All in all, a very satisfactory result and one which left me feeling that the practice cared and was making sure that everything was as it should be.

author: eldestson
title: End of Life Care
body: The Knoll Hospital in Duns, Berwickshire responded quickly to provide a bed for my Mother. The care for my Mother was personal and excellent. In addition they provided first class support to the family.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Brilliant Surgery - exceptional service
body: I just wanted to give some positive feedback to the Practice on the exceptional service they are providing at the moment. I've had to use the eConsult service twice and phone the Practice once in the last month, and my queries and health concerns have been dealt with so quickly and efficiently - and with care. Thank you.

author: shortywits
title: Still no-one calling me back
body: I was booked to have an MRI and CT Scan and then it was cancelled and then I recieved a letter saying it was on hold. Then I was told to contact Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch to re-schedule and I requested to go to Nuffield as there was less risk for me there and they said they would call back but they didn't. I know this is a difficult time but I am in constant pain and really need help with my spinal problems and my hip.I have tried calling Bournemouth and Christchurch and am told on the phone the times I can call, which I have adhered to, but still no-one calling me back and I can't get through to Outpatient appointments in either Hospital. Is there anything you could help with please?

readBy.name: The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Quick turnaround
body: I completed an online form this morning that goes direct to the Doctors asking for a prescription  for an urgent issue. The form stated I’d be contacted by the end of the next day. I was actually contacted within 30 minutes, had a telephone consultation and prescription sent to pharmacy immediately.  That is a fantastic response in anyone’s books especially as we are in the middle of COVID-19.  Really superb .

title: Pleasant experience
body:
I visited the practice today after the telephone consultation. The doctor I saw was very pleasant natured, she took her time to go through issues I had and very patiently listened to me, rightly referred me for an X-ray which I was hoping she would. What I liked best was her friendliness and warmth which many forget to display during the current pandemic. She was well covered  in PPE, which was excellent, she did not hesitate at all to do the required necessary 
examination. The fact that she has always treated patients with respect & never hesitates in referring if it’s necessary builds my respect for her. Thank you doctor.
A suggestion- it would be a good idea for the surgery to have little sanitising gel stations here and there,, there’s only one at the entrance.

title: Not supportive for pregnant during covid 19
body: I found out during lockdown that I’m pregnant. Contacted surgery and genuinely told them about change of address and asked how can I now make sure I do have gp. Was told to write email asking to keep me until I will be able to register to another surgery. I did that, was sent form to sign which again I did and sent back. And 2 months after I have received letter dated for 9 days before saying I have one month to move to another surgery. In the meantime had number of phone conversations when I have explained that surgeries are not accepting patients now or simply don’t pick up the phones. Nobody cared... I went again to another surgery begging to be registered but was told that due to Covid19 I have to wait.. I am 15 weeks pregnant and Trevelyan House management can’t absolutely allow me to stay few more months after being their patient for over 10 years. I was always very happy with their service but lack of understanding and “duty of care” is disgusting at this point. I guess the management who made that “strict” decision has never been pregnant. In 20 days I will be without GP half way my pregnancy.

title: Always helpful
body: Every time I have contacted this surgery, they have been polite, helpful and efficient. Reception staff are knowledgeable and helpful, and the doctors are always excellent.

author: Theoptimist
title: Recovery from alcoholism
body:
I returned to the UK after living abroad for a long time battling with alcoholism. I had tried rehab twice overseas and was still struggling. It had resulted in the loss of my marriage, my family unit, my job and the life I loved so much. I was very ill, both mentally and physically. I was at a very low point in my life and couldn’t see how any support or treatment could work. I was left feeling hopeless and lost.  
I immediately began seeking all the care and support services I could. Through the GP I was able to get physically assessed and admitted and was treated brilliantly to restore me back to full health. I contacted CGL and the Wellbeing services, both who provided me with ongoing support and guidance. I was treated as a human with an illness, not with disdain or disgust which meant a huge deal to me at the time following my fall from grace. Thankfully, with their support and on going relentless positivity I am now nearly 8 months sober, a previously unthinkable achievement.

title: Prompt and very friendly response.
body: I really like the online consultation followed by a telephone call then an appointment if required.  The last doctor I spoke to was very friendly and put me at ease straight away.  I am really happy with the practice since the introduction if online consultation.

title: Incredible Staff
body: I went in for a coloscopy. There were three people doing this procedure for me. I entered the room very nervous as I’ve never had this done before, but they all put me at ease. They explained exactly what would happen and exactly what the different outcomes could be. We had a lovely chat during the procedure which took my mind off what was happening. They were all genuinely so kind, helpful, informative, and I could not have wished for a better experience. Thank you.

readBy.name: Yeovil District Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practise
body:
I was scared of begging, and panicking, because didn’t know what to expect how painful it will be . I was 7 weeks pregnant, 
And I have  vacuum aspiration . I went to hospital at 10:50 and I wan been out 15;00 
The nurses was so kind and so much look after you , didn’t left you any minute alone. 
They are so nice . And I promise if you are worried, don’t . Because they will do everything for you and you are in a good hands

title: Confidentiality issues
body:
Not for the first time I am left fuming after a phone conversation with a receptionist. Firstly, she informed me the doctor I saw on Friday for whom I wished to leave a medical message (for her benefit, more than mine) was ill. Had the doctor given the receptionist permission to share that information? Secondly, having that information leaves me worried that the doctor might have been infectious with covid. Should I now be waiting for a Track and Trace phone call, as the examination was the only risk I have had since the pandemic took hold? Lastly, I was pressed to give more information than was necessary for the message to be useful to the doctor. I wish I hadn't bothered, as it did me no good.
The doctors are excellent. The receptionists are lacking in skills. This was not a new receptionist. I hope the call was recorded, as I shall ask the practice manager to review it.

title: Brilliant reception staff
body: Have had occasion to ring the surgery over the past few days and the two receptionists I spoke to have been so helpful.  A big thank you.

title: COVID-19 social prescriber contact
body: I had a call today from the COVID-19 social prescriber to see how I am coping as an extremely vulnerable person. She was both really friendly and very professional. Although I don't need any help (apart from a vaccine!) I can see it is a really good service that the local health authority has set up and would be especially useful for people needing mental health or social support. Excellent.

title: Amazing practice
body: I asked for a non urgent appointment during the COVID pandemic. A doctor called me that afternoon, was so kind and understanding, arranged an appointment for 2 days later and told me when he would call me back with the results. The nurse at the surgery was brilliant, the processes for dealing with the virus situation were so clear and the whole experience was excellent. I cannot think of how the surgery could be better and thank you to all the team for such a great support.

title: Thank you for such a caring service
body: I was admitted through A&E on Tues 19th May and stayed in 5 days. I had/have a possible issue with the settings on my pacemaker.  I was on Wards 20 and 22. I had great service, care and attention from 111, the paramedics, A&E and both of the wards. All the staff I came in touch with were caring and compassionate which is just what I needed. I am now going through the follow up which has been prompt and efficient. Thank you so much to everyone who was involved with my care. It is much appreciated especially in the trying circumstances we have at the moment. Keep up the great work, you are all a credit to the NHS. SMH

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Helpful receptionists and technical staff
body: I had difficulties accessing online services. The technical staff at the Practice were a great help with this

title: Highly professional and kind.
body:
Whipps X paramedics 'A Positive' and 'B Positive' responded very quickly and were brilliant, treating me like an old friend en route to A.& E. All necessary tests and checks were carried out promptly and efficiently in A.& E.  I was kept fully informed at all times by both the doctor and nursing staff and could not have asked for better or kinder treatment
A wonderful family of carers not forgetting the helpful auxiliary staff. I was able to return home the same day, 30th May, in time for my wife's birthday the next day. Phew!
If possible please pass on my thanks to the London Ambulance Service team who were based at Whipps Cross.

title: Great Practice
body: Have been going to this surgery for the last 25 year.  I have always found the staff to be helpful even when busy.  Even though its a small surgery and they have tried to expand, they are a lot better than others in the area and the doctors have all been professional and helpful. It's so nice to find doctors that take the time to explain thinks to you and make sure that you are leaving your appointment well informed and reassured. We recommend them to anyone seeking a new GP.

title: Outstanding practice
body: Since a difficult time last year this practice has gone above and beyond to help me. Every GP/ANP and nurse I have seen has been so caring and understanding. Could not fault them at all.

title: Upset and heartbroken.
body: I phoned this clinic after speaking to the 111 service and was told id be contacted by a nurse. The nurse who rang me i am unsure of her name, was extremely rude, didn't seem to understand that I was explaining my symptoms and how they were not related to a medical condition I have (I work for a private ambulance service so have indepth knowledge regarding such conditions) she didn't seem to take me concern seriously and told he she can't do anything, she quizzed me as to why my condition was urgent while continuing to speak to me in an unprofessional Manor. She laughed at me when I tried to explain that I was unable to get to A&E and would rather not attend in an ambulance. Having explained that I had previously been to the doctors with this as I had been struggling and it has got worse today, I told her I couldn't get an appointment and it felt like someone was kneeling on my chest, I could take deep breath in but feel like I cant breathe out. She didn't seem to care and was still speaking to me like im an uneducated toddler. The conclusion to this was that I will never use the walk in clinic again and have lost faith in the service providers employed there. The receptionist at the time was really lovely and seemed to genuinely try and help while asking questions. I got laughed at for the way in which I use my inhalers and despite explaining to her that it is not asthma like symptoms and they had no effect she was still adamant i was fine. She criticised me for not going to my GP around my busy working schedule, I will have to make an appointment with my GP to resolve the issue tomorrow as I spend the night feeling annoyed, upset and angered by the way I was treated. I dont mean to criticise the service as I understand it is a challenging profession as I work in the same type of condition, but no matter what no one who is concerned about their health, let alone having a respiratory issue should be dismissed and laughed at regardless of their circumstances.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Couchie bear
title: All the workers do a brilliant job.
body:
The staff as in doctors, nurses, nursing assistants, porters and cleaners were all fantastic and they did they very best to make sure you were comfortable and well cared for, I was down a couple of times as my husband who also looks after me at home wasn't allowed in to see me, the nurses would come along and always made me feel better.  
There was one day when I went down hill very quickly and the doctors and nurses were brilliant and they made sure my husband was kept in the picture even when they were looking at sending me to icu. Others must understand that there is some very poorly people on the ward who must come first. So I would like to say a very big thank you to all who work there as they do a brilliant job thank you

title: Ridiculous waiting times
body: This surgery never changes! You have to ring at 8 on the dot to get an appointment. If you are one of the lucky ones that manage to get one then make sure you are prepared to wait for anything between 30-60 minutes because they are NEVER on time!

author: Ged4400
title: Everyone was absolutely fantastic
body: Was admitted to RAH after testing positive for Covid-19, can’t recall at the time phoning my wife to say I was getting put into an induced Coma and on to a Ventilator. Spent 9 days in a coma after my wife was told I was critical and not sure if I would pull through. When I came round I had no idea what I had experienced, relying on the fantastic Doctors and Nurses who cared for me.I was quite delusional for the first few days and very emotional and could not stop crying over the littlest of things. Everyone was absolutely fantastic with me and when I managed to get my speech back, I had great conversations with all the nurses. I was then transferred to Ward 23 and special thanks to Adele Kirsty and Hayleigh, who could not do enough for me to make my stay in the ward as easy as possible. Unfortunately I ended up with a chest and UTI and had to spend a few extra days in the ward. Missing my family when I felt I was ready to go home. I would explain my after effects as complete fatigue, all my bones are sore and I believe this can last for weeks. I am lucky that I had some form of mobility, but still need to exercise as I feel quite often unstable in my balance. Will be a long road to recovery but taking each day as it comes will help. Mental anguish could be another issue, at one point during my return to my home, I was frightened to get to sleep and ended up putting the light in for comfort. Thankfully that only lasted for a couple of days. I know I am one of the fortunate ones, but without the care and dedication of the ICU staff, I would not be able to tell my tale. My only concern is, I have no one else to speak with who has experienced what I have went through and feel it would be great, if there was some form of contact, that I can speak with but they are just as unaware of best practice due to this new virus.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: avon71
title: Care, compassion and patience
body: Everyone who has visited from IRIS has shown care, compassion and patience. There have been various teams visiting my mum in the past but you are like no other.

author: Dr B
title: Communication during lockdown
body: Over 18 hrs my husband presented 3 episodes of speech difficulty that he quickly recovered from each time. I finally called 111 and when I got through after 2 hours and after 30 minutes was advised that he should go to bed and contact the GP in the morning. He was admitted for an overnight stay that turned out to be for 6 days. We managed that bit with the help of my niece in lockdown. I was satisfied with his treatment. The huge problem I had was not knowing things at home on my own (with my sister in a care home with a severe chest infection alongside; I am not considered to be next of kin for her as she has family, so cannot even get information if I phone about her. ). With Crosshouse, my husband had forgotten his phone charger. We had to pace calls now and again, during which he had speech difficulties occasionally. One time a nurse helped by lending her charger (Thanks! That just lifted the constant fear for a while: bless you! ). I tried to phone the ward once and after waiting 45 minutes with the very considerate telephone operator, got through only to hear the ward sounds and my call be hung up as soon as I started to say hello! I was furious and just completely broke down. On his last day my husband found that he could have made calls to me or me to him by a phone on the ward attached to a tv, even without charge, but the money would never have been an issue, Nobody bothered to tell him. They had no idea what I was going through alone over a hundred miles from family and being housebound due to lockdown.

author: John Doe 57
title: Addiction and bereavement
body: I had a long addiction to alcohol. And recently lost my long time partner. I have been sober now for over 12 months, but since lockdown and loosing my partner I am determined not to go back. I have had excellent support via zoom from the staff at the Priory hospital in Chelmsford. Also would like to praise CGL in Cambridgeshire, especially Adrian and Andrea for the excellent support, by group meetings and also on the end of the phone. I wouldn’t have been able to get through this without there help. Not to mention the fantastic support given by my peers in the group’s

author: tups
title: Very professional treatment
body: Want to thank everyone at the endoscopy dept. Had my colon explored. All staff cheerful and knowledgeable, put me at ease. Very professional treatment. A big thank you to everyone.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Huatulco
title: Offering no support during Covid-19
body: I previously wrote about this 3 months ago and still haven't been assessed by this service. I understand that the recent pandemic has made things very different but I am now being told there is NO support available from this service. Instead they advised me via the Feedback service to speak to a neuropsychologist. The neuropsychologist told me to speak to liaison psychiatry. So what should I do? In the meantime I have lost my ability to deal with my own finances, and have twice been told this week that doctors spoke to me of which I have absolutely no memory. So any advice, treatment plans I just have no means of accessing because people refuse to give me the help I need. Today I set the grill on fire and only found it by seeing smoke from under the kitchen door. I'm trying desperately to help myself but knowing these people don't seem to care is very difficult. If anybody out there knows what else there is available instead of the seemingly defunct Liaison Psychiatry service then I'd be grateful to hear about it.

title: Endoscopy unit
body: On 11/05/2020  I attended the unit for endoscopy. I waited 5mins. I was greeted by staff and made ti feel totally at ease. The 3 female staff were professional  knowledgeable and extremely understanding at all times the procedure was quick and painless after ste was explained to me and even had tea and biscuits when procedure was over. Thankyou to the 3 staff excellent profession service absolutely faultless

readBy.name: St Helens and Knowsley Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Excellent Home Visit
body: Previously i've not been the biggest fan of Heathcote Medical Centre however one constant that has always impressed me has been the ladies working reception/telephone who have always been kind, understanding and super professional. Anyway now on to the actual home visit a few days ago. Basically the GP thoroughly impressed me. He quickly concluded that i should attend hosp to be looked over - he then made the necessary call for an ambulance etc. During the visit he listened to my grumbles and even brought a smile to my face with a couple of humorous quips. Thank you Doctor + thank you Heathcote!

title: Great all round experience THANK YOU
body: Having spoke to a very empathetic receptionist, my Mother’s GP called me back. Her level of understanding, kindness and professionalism were outstanding. Thanks to her and the support team, my Mother has had an exceptional NHS experience, in what are extremely challenging times. Thank you.

title: Brilliant practice
body: Every time I have visited or contacted the surgery the Doctors and staff have always been friendly, helpful and knowledgeable cannot fault their performance in any way.

title: Superb Care
body: In May my father spent 10 days in the Fitzwilliam Ward.  Despite the pandemic and him being nearly 94 years old, his care was superb in every single way.  He ended his life there by gently slipping away.  I was locked down in central France so couldn’t travel to see him, yet I feel very calm and tranquil whenever I think of his death.  The nurses frequently assured me I could telephone for news at any time, including the middle of the night.  Thank you Malton Hospital for giving me this precious gift of such a memory of my father’s death.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Mum-2-3
title: My maternity journey
body: I was incredibly well supported by Diane and the Bluebell team of midwives under NHS Grampian throughout my pregnancy, birth and up to my discharge from midwifery care. I couldn't have asked for a more mother-centred midwife, Diane was absolutely fantastic and she made me feel comfortable and confident, she was always clear that everything was my choice and gave me the information and support needed to make informed choices. I felt complete trust in her and am very grateful to have been part of her caseload, she treated me and my family with respect and kindness at all times.

title: Need improvement
body:
I am a person who dislike going to GP, if I’m sick, I rather go to boots and pick up the medicine. But this time I would like to see my GP as I am struggle to deal with my Folliculitis (specially summer is around the Corner) specially this condition has spreading to other part of my body. 

I had my first GP appointment in Nov and ask my GP for advice. I appreciated for GP’s help, but I believe she gave me the wrong prescription (the cream doesn’t work for me as it was for dry skin and eczema), so I wait a long period of time to see if my skin condition are getting any better, but sadly no. So I recently I booked another appointment and hopefully my GP will help me out. First my appointment is at 2:45pm, and doctor didn’t called me until almost 5pm. I had to call the practice to make sure my appointment still valid around 4ish. And Doctor only spend around 10 mins or even less...  to me and tell me this is the way I born to be and said it shouldn’t bother me, but come on! It does bothering me! I suppose to go to the doctor for help, not judgments! So at the end no prescription... but she said  will refer my case? let’s see how it goes... but honestly I have no hope for my GP at all...

title: Caring and supportive staff
body: My husband and I experienced a late miscarriage and went to the maternity unit to deliver our baby. The staff was incredibly caring in this difficult time. We got plenty of support. Thank you so much to all the midwifes, doctors, nurses, anaesthetist and hospital staff that cared for us, even just a few minutes, it made this distressful experience more bearable for us. You have done such a great job.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Amazing Practise
body:
My husband and I and my sister, have been fortunate to be within the catchment area for this practice for 5+ years.
Without exception, we have all been well cared for and have felt completely protected by each member of staff dealing with our needs.
Thank you so much to all those whom we have asked for help from this practise. We have never been let down by any one of you.
Thank you so much.

title: Award Winning Practice
body: I've never been treated by an award-winning practice. I'm very happy with Richmond Rd; I wish I had family in the borough to recommend them to. I'm so happy with them, when my life moves on, I'll be really sad to have to find a new surgery. I always get an appointment when I need it and the call back service really works for me-it's bliss! The reception staff are really nice and it's obviously a nice place to work. Well done Richmond Rd! Keep it up!

title: Wonderful experience
body: Visited A&E with a service user from the care home I work at. I could not fault the service he received from beginning to end. Every single doctor, nurse and healthcare assistant was extremely kind and patient when dealing with a very complex individual. I was understandably nervous about visiting a hospital due to the coronavirus but I felt very safe immediately upon arrival. It was obvious that staff were taking every precaution and were incredibly pleasant, reassuring and patient during these very stressful times.

author: LalaLand
title: A very smooth process
body: I attended after hurting my arm earlier in the day whilst out on my bike. Immediately when I arrived at Minor Injuries, I noticed the atmosphere was very relaxed and informal. It was also very calm. I didn’t have to wait that long to be seen and the nurse who saw me, Leon, was great with me. He really put me at ease and was very thorough in how he examined my arm. I had to get my arm x-rayed. This felt quite seamless and the process very smooth. Again the radiographer, Mafi, was lovely with me; very calm and patient. From entering Minor Injuries to leaving with a sling, I would highly praise the place. I’m very anxious in hospitals however I felt very calm in there today.

author: DdGM
title: They are all angels
body:
My mum is in Bridgeview Care Home, Dundee and we are astounded by the care and compassion given to my mum during this extremely difficult time.  
The staff need to be recognized for their high levels of knowledge, compassion and nonstop care they have given my mum, and patience they constantly give to me.  
My mum was seriously ill a couple of weeks ago yet they did their utmost for her and pulled her through, the love and constant care they give her is above and beyond, they looked after her so well that she is still here. Without their nonstop care and compassion we are sure my mum would have passed.  
They are all angels, who we have the utmost respect for.  
They are just so kind, professional and dedicated to their patients, this has been obvious right from the start, April 2019, a year on its just heartwarming to know that our mother has been and still is, in the best of care.  
Care homes are having such a difficult time, well it's about time they were recognized for the angels who work there.

author: Leia
title: Staff smoking on site
body:
I left my dad at this hospital mortuary last year only to be greeted by various staff members all smoking whilst in uniform (opposite the mortuary door entrance). I have seen many NHS Trust staff smoke throughout the hospital grounds without any challenge from security staff or other hospital staff, despite the hospital claiming it has a "STRICT no smoking policy"(??)  
There is NOTHING "strict" about this hospital with regards to no-smoking on site. I wish they'd just do away with the signage if they can't keep staff in check or have no desire to honour their own 'no-smoking' policy. Many of the staff smoke outside the main entrance of the hospital in full view of others; they also smoke outside the A&E department; they also smoke opposite the mortuary, and they also smoke on the left-side grass embankment at the road entrance to the hospital in full view of drivers and passers by.  
What sort of message does this send to members of the public or to people who might potentially want to work at the hospital? Why should vulnerable patients such as asthmatics, COPD patients, patients with heart conditions, cystic fibrosis etc. be put at risk?  
I think they should, as a hospital, do the same as other hospitals and organisations and put tannoys up around the hospital requesting people not to smoke in designated areas? At least be shown to be trying to make a difference. Also, why not have security cameras set up in 'smoking hotspots' to deter employees from smoking and to identify those who require support.  
How is this country ever going to be 'Smokefree' by 2030 if even health organisations can't get actively on board?

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

author: lionwr88
title: My therapy
body:
When it happened a story for my life.He lied to me and used me for prostitution 😥  
I was very bad while now I am better because I can share protected where I stay and the therapy. Therapy has done me a lot of good because I'm slowly to forget what happened to me. I did not sleep all night.  
Now I'm slowly to forget about that.  
Thanks a lot my therapy Amach...  
I heartily hope that not a single woman goes through what happened to me because it is terrible.

author: Confused carer
title: Guidance for visitors
body:
Recently my mother was admitted to hospital, something she was not happy with to start off with but it was for the best and she complied. On arrival we realised there may be issues with restricted visiting etc which we accepted. We were allowed onto the ward where the doctor had notes regarding her shared care plan and her other exceptional circumstances including severe mental health. Doctors and nurse were both made aware and I was able to stay with her during the initial consultation but told I would not be able to go on the ward. We asked to go home to get a few things and get mum prepared for her stay which we did on the return the rules changed and I was able to settle her on the ward which with her personal situation was very much appreciated. Morning came and I was asked by the nurse to bring mums medication which I did. This time I was not able to get passed the door, again I understood as I was only dropping items off. As a type 1 diabetic the patient had to be kept as nil by mouth so my mother had nothing to eat from around 2.30am and that was items I had provided. Through regular phone calls with her at 1.30pm when she still had not had her procedure I asked to speak to the nurse. The nurse taking care of my mum was more concerned with why I was on site for my mother's well being than why she had not had the procedure. I was made aware by some of the previous days nurses that they were waiting for the Covid test - something that had not been communicated with my mother. Explaining the situations and all my mothers medical issues the nurse dismissed me and stated I would need to vacate the area and call up to find out about my mother. I did as asked and made contact by phone. I was then told there was no change and I would need to call at 4pm.  
Through regular contact with my mother she asked if I could charge her phone and she began to worry about the fact she had been given a menu for later as well as the next day which had made her anxious and she began stating she would stay. To calm her I agreed to come and collect her phone from reception on the ward as well as the menu to complete for her. On approaching the ward a nurse allowed me in which I asked several times as previously I had been told this would not be possible the nurse lead me to my mother and I calmed only to have the nurse taking care of my mother again inform me that this was incorrect and no one else had visitors and I would have to leave. Understandably confused as I had informed the member of staff about the situation. I asked about the mitigating circumstances that would possibly let allow me to be with my mother and was told it only covered palliative patients. I asked at reception if there was a list of mitigating circumstances and was informed they were unaware of any but PALS may be able to help. As I have to return the phone to my mother I have been informed by the nurse that I will need to go to the main reception and leave personal effects there for them to be collect by the nurses. I asked at reception and was told this was not the case. This whole situation has left my mother and my family very disappointed for the first time using the QE. My mother has many procedures on the horizon that will require lengthy stays and this will affect her beyond this interaction and her mental state going forward.

author: firewm94
title: Quick GP referral
body:
Last week I was struggling with pain and moving my bowels, after trying to move them I realised I was bleeding from my back passage and the pain was increasing. I decided to call my GP's surgery and ask them to make a note on my file, they have been investigating dietary issues for a while with me.  
When I called in, there was a recorded message on how to order your repeated prescription now and what to do if you have suspected covid19 symptoms. There was also information on only being offered a face-to-face appointment if deemed necessary by the GP after a phone appointment.  
Once through the receptionist asked what the appointment would be in regards to, I said dietary issues. She informed me the Doctor would call back within the hour, and they did.  
I explained my symptoms to the GP and she asked some routine questions. She asked if it was possible for me to come to the surgery, I was surprised as I hadn't expected to be seen in person. I was asked to wear a mask and gloves before arriving, and to ring the bell and step back from the main door. The receptionist checked my name and who I was to see and asked me to wait at the side door.  
The GP opened the side door, she was wearing full PPE, gloves, mask, apron and a face screen protector. I was taken in to the examination room, it was very clean and had no extra equipment, just the desk, a chair and the examination table.  
The Doctor asked me some questions and then asked to do a physical examination, it was a very routine appointment apart from the PPE we were both wearing. She was able to take my blood pressure while I wore the gloves, I have honestly never felt safer in the surgery.  
She left to make a call, to a Doctor at the QUEH and they wanted see me as soon as possible. I was really shocked and seriously struggling to believe her, but she gave me a note of where to go and who to ask for. She checked I had more gloves and masks to wear while attending and explained that there was a completely separate entrance for non covid19 patients.  
I went home and fed my dog then went straight to the hospital, driven by my husband. Most of you will know getting to the QEUH can be a challenge, it was 5 o'clock and we made it in 20 mins from the Hampden area of Glasgow.  
The hospital was so quiet, it was kind of eerie, I've never noticed what an imposing site it is when it's not busy. Husband dropped me at the drop off section and I went in alone. It had been explained I couldn't take anyone with me as waiting areas were observing social distancing rules.  
The non covid19 entrance was very clearly marked and I met 2 people who checked why I was there and that I wasn't experiencing any Covid19 related symptoms. There were markings on the floor like at the supermarket to keep you 2 meters from the next person. The revolving doors are wedged open so you don't have to crowd in or touch anything. There is hand sanitizer at the door for anyone to use.  
I asked the main receptionist from the taped off area for directions and want straight through to the department. The door was locked so I had to push a buzzer and wait to be admitted. Again met by a nurse wearing full PPE who checked my details and asked me to wait in the seating area. There were 3 other people waiting and every 2nd chaired was marked not to be sat on. You never try to sit close to someone in the Doctors or hospital waiting room but this felt weird. We were actively trying to stay as far apart as possible. It was very effective, no one was any closer than 10ft with the chairs and marked areas to direct travel.  
I took a book to read and it helped to pass the time before and after my initial intake examination. Both the intake nurse and the assistant she had were dressed in full PPE, while taking blood and having internal exams. I honestly don't know why that isn't what they always use. It made me feel so much more comfortable in general about the spread of germs, I am very aware of the ease of transmission in simple things like colds and this was such a sterile feeling situation. I normally experience stress in these situations due to the high volume of people the hospital surgeries see, this visit was a completely different experiences  
When I was seen by the Doctor they again wore full PPE during the consultation and I kept my mask on, I was able to take my gloves off once I was in the room. She was able to examine me fully with out any concerns about transmission of anything.  
It was very reassuring to know they were all well catered for in the forms of PPE, from the GP's receptionist right they way through to the hospital on call Doctor. The instructions given to me were very clear and what I was told matched what I experienced.  
While I wasn't expecting to go to hospital I'm glad I did, I'm glad the Doctor had time to see me and so quickly. I'm really glad she did, me and my bum are on the mend. I'm scheduled for more tests and unless I experience a big change in symptoms ill get them when normal services return.  
I wanted to let anyone out there who is putting off speaking to their GP about new or increased symptoms - don't!  
They want to see you, they want to help and so do the hospital staff. It is frightening to go to hospital at any time, it's especially frightening during the covid19 outbreak, but it is being done safely, for staff and patients. They all understand long term health conditions haven't stopped because of covid19.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Miserable bunch
body: Just dropped by to deliver our midwife letter. Had 3 day old in pram.  Reception so engrossed in their conversation they couldn’t even bring themselves to say congratulations.  We’ve all been tested and passed as Covid free,  as part of the birth and the reception was totally empty. Oh well.

author: Mrs-H
title: Very impressed with how staff have adapted
body: Very impressed with how the staff at Glasgow Dental School have adapted to manage emergency patients during pandemic. Professionalism, infection control and care was excellent. I am particularly grateful to Gareth and his team for doing such an amazing job. Wearing PPE with no air conditioning and sun beaming is clearly so difficult for staff making us more grateful than ever!

title: Absolutely fantastic service
body:
The three ladies working on Monday 1st June 2020 around 7pm starting from reception Through to nurse we’re absolute diamonds!

I attended due to a torn off finger nail which has started with an infection and from the phone call at 645pm to visiting and leaving was seamless and complete in 40 mins! 

A great bunch of ladies doing a great job !

THANK YOU 

Mr Wright

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Frosties
title: A visit to A and E
body: I was in a great deal of pain before my visit and was feeling very apprehensive. Great care from all of the staff.

author: Jaycee12
title: A minor procedure
body: Was treated today at Stirling Community Dermatology Department for a minor procedure. I was seen by David and Lesley who were both fantastic examples of how Nursing should be. They were both courteous, compassionate, kind, professional and knowledgeable. As a nurse myself, I found their professionalism an inspiration, I can only hope that my patients are as satisfied with my care.

readBy.name: Office of Angus MacDonald, MSP for Falkirk East

author: Pags
title: Detox
body: I received excellent service especially as it’s lockdown. Kaman was just brilliant. She should be commended

author: Satisfaction
title: They were all tremendous
body: Had to call for a ambulance as my wife had been taken I’ll at B&Q. The two from the ambulance was so good towards my wife and self kept us very assured what was going on after taking her to the hospital with me not allowed in the A&E doctor came out and gave me an update on what was going on put my mind at rest so overall from start to finish they were all tremendous and should be all proud of themselves

title: Kind And Caring
body: Life is so different due to this Covid crisis, and for all the difficulties that it must cause, you are still treated with kindness and compassion by the wonderful staff at this surgery.   I have been with this surgery for years, there have been ups and downs and unfortunately with age came a reliance on these services,  but there is none better.  Thank you to you all, but especially those in reception for the kindness you show.

title: Outstanding care and treatment
body: From diagnosis through to the last six months of treatment and consultation reviews, follow-ups and ongoing medication needs, I could not possibly have asked for a higher level of care for my bone marrow cancer (myeloma). From the consultants through to every care professional encountered, Royal Derby Hospital has provided me with outstanding care and treatment, and I cannot recommend the hospital too highly. It is everything that you would want an NHS service to be. Congratulations all round!

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Awesome
body: After having so many issues in the past with drs and consultants the most recent one changed my opinion of them. He proved to me there are good quality drs out there still. I can't fault him or his staff one bit. They worked well and collaborated with my other consultants to make sure I was getting the right procedure and having it done the right way with the least risks to my life whilst still managing my pain. Bravo.

readBy.name: North West Anglia NHS Foundation Trust

title: Out of this world!
body:
My husband was admitted to the ward for palliative End of life care. Even though we were mid coronavirus the staff showed compassion and kindness and allowed me to visit ( fully ppe equipped of course). They acknowledged the positive impact this would have on us both. I cannot thank everyone enough for the way they looked after us both in a peaceful, comfortable environment where my husband was treated with care and dignity right up to his last breath.
Another wonderful experience demonstrating the excellence that is our NHS.

title: Rude receptionist  - ruining this Sugery
body: I’ve been considering leaving this practice for some time, mainly due to the rude and unprofessional receptionist that is employed by this Practice. There are other receptionists, and their standard is very good, just this one person causing humiliation and anger. The GPs are very good in general. I hope these reviews are taken seriously and read / acted upon by the management of this surgery; you need to sort out the ‘bad apple’ within your reception staff and ensure they’re properly trained to carry out their job politely to me (and others - the ‘customers’).  Also, when calling it’s also very unprofessional to have the telephone answered by a voice saying “can you hold the line please”.   Really? Please consider employing the use of an answering service if you cannot answer your calls, or having a brief message on the line to let a caller know their call is acknowledged and their position in the queue.

title: Wonderful practice
body: I rang the limes monday morning very worried i told receptionist i had blood in my urine. She said dr would ring me. And he did. He was very kind talked it through with me very reassuring   so a big thank you from me

title: Superb!
body: Having called 111 and been advised to attend A&E for urgent treatment I arrived at 9pm. I was  checked in by the receptionist then triaged by a nurse all within 10 minutes.  I then had to wait only 25 minutes to be seen by a consultant. Treatment was provided together with medications to take away with me. All staff provided their names and were calm and supportive. The seating area had been set up to ensure social distancing and their was a sense of everything being under control.  Thank you to all staff.

title: AMAZING!
body: Even in the depths of this pandemic, I was referred for a follow up procedure from Southmead hospital. The treatment I received was second to none. The care offered  by staff was outstanding from the nurse receiving me from reception who I had already watched running up 2 flights of stairs after putting patients in the lift (for social distancing), the anaesthetist who listened to my fears and gave me just enough sedation that I slept through the whole thing to, the nurse who sat with me through 2 cups of tea chatting about the prospect of sending her son back to school. I have nothing but respect and praise for the all doctors and nurses who supported me. Would highly recommend. Thank you

title: Great GP Surgery
body: I have found this Practice to be excellent! I have always been able to get appts straight away if needed and found the care to be brilliant. Compared to the stories you hear of other GP Surgeries, this is top class! Thank you.

title: Sympathetic care
body: I visited the Endoscopy Department on 30/05/20 for a colonoscopy procedure and was feeling very nervous however all the staff were kind and helpful and put me at ease before, during and after the procedure. I was well taken care of at all times and despite the caronavirus situation adding to the worry and stress I was reassured that I was safe at all times. Thanks to all the staff involved, you are all truly amazing.

title: Call back - Awful receptionist
body: Telephone call. I find it unacceptable to have such an passive aggressive reception.. I understand it’s a pandemic at the moment but the lack of customer service/ interpersonal skill blows my mind. This should not be acceptable.

author: PidgRace
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I thank each and every one of you
body:
I was sent a letter with an enclosed 'Personal exercise programme'. It was very helpful to have the images printed on a separate sheet of paper. Strokes are strange events, not so much affecting past learning and memories but definitely recent instructions and unfamiliar processes, such as your exercises. Jean is great and persuades me each day to do your routines, counting the repeats out aloud. She has become my 'live in' Kate, which is definitely a great help and I would be lost without her. For a start my meals would be non-existent and over time I would probably starve!  
  
Please give my best wishes to all your colleagues who have helped so positively with my care, especially big Chris and little Chris who I have not forgotten. Rhea is still there in the background helping with my driving plans and I am grateful for that. However when I think of Rhea I also recall images of pegs on the edge of her tin and some strange coloured 'putty' that just will NOT cut! I am convinced she makes this herself, at night, by the light of a full moon!I appreciate that with the coronavirus and the necessary nationwide avoidance of contact I am unlikely to meet most of your team again. However I do thank each and every one of you for the part you have played in my recovery and wish you all a safe journey through these alarming times.

title: unable to communicate wiht staff team
body: Unable to have a call answered by reception, phone keep on  getting cut off. This is the front line access for clients, carers and anyone in crisis. Have to do better this is totally unacceptable.

readBy.name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

author: Jwp79
title: Alcohol addiction
body: I’ve suffered with addiction for some time now. I hope to totally be free from alcohol. I’m 40 yrs old and I’m a lover of life when not drinking. The staff here have gone above and beyond

title: Calming radiographer
body:
I had never had an MRI before, and was a little nervous. The radiographer met me, talked me through what would happen and then wheeled me slowly round to the room. He made me feel very relaxed and I was able to remain calm through the whole process. I think going at a calm, unhurried pace was good, if he had made me feel rushed it would have been counterproductive and taken much longer in the end as 20 minutes inside a noisy machine could easily have set off a panic attack but it did not. After my scan I left the room smiling.
I wished I had said a bigger thank you in person at the time so
Thank you. Please tell your staff thank you.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: Excellent care and support in WGH
body: Thank you to all the staff who have supported me through my recent injuries. I am very grateful for the kindness, care and good humour in Urgent Care and Outpatients. I hope we always have the choice to attend WGH and that it thrives in the future. Congratulations to all staff through this difficult time and keep up the good work.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust

title: So glad I transferred to this practice
body:
I have had but very positive experiences since I transferred to this practice in January 2019.  The reception staff have always been very polite and helpful, especially during the lockdown, one receptionist went more than the proverbial mile sorting out a prescription for me.  The nursing staff have also been very helpful and friendly in helping me manage COPD and taking blood tests.  The three GPs I have seen have been marvellous, taking time to listen and making sure they understand my concerns and have been very conscientious in arranging for further hospital tests to be carried out. They have also looked at my medication and suggested I cut down on one which has made my "restless legs" a lot easier. It has been very difficult in lockdown but it has been made easier by the contacts this practice has made, making me feel that I am well looked after. Thank you so much
K Dykes

title: Mid wife was so horrible
body: I visited for my first pregnancy scan today 2nd June 2020. This mid wife I saw today was so horrible and rude. She had no manners, didn’t even reply to my hello or say hi, how are you. If she doesn’t like her job she shouldn’t be there. I’m sure for all the mothers it’s happy occasion where they get to see baby first or second time. But this lady was there for sake of and made me feel like so bad. I felt so disappointed after my visit. I will recommend to other people please chose different hospital if you have options. Thanks
